prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In the publication by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. in Physica A 564 (2021) with reference to Figure 2, each social layer of the proposed multi-layer network is depicted. The nodes in the network represent people and are consistent across all layers, while the weighted connections indicate social interactions that could potentially lead to transmission of infection based on the edge weight (a probability value within the range of 0 to 1). The initial layer represents interactions within households, with groups of varying sizes that are fully connected internally. These groups have no connections to external networks, essentially forming disconnected components that represent individual families. To determine the composition of each group, the research incorporates the distribution of Argentine family sizes in 2011, ranging from 1 to 14 members, with consideration given to the likelihood of families having sizes between 1 and 10. Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Fig. 2(a) shows the structure of such a layer built for a
post_context: . Most of the population in any given country is involved in some form of economic activity, necessitating social interaction through work. This highlights the significance of work in social relations, especially during an epidemic. To model work connectivity, we propose a generic layer connecting individuals aged 18 to 59, encompassing 60% of Argentina's population. Creating a realistic connection rule is challenging due to the diverse job types and companies. We suggest a scenario with random groups ranging from 5 to 30 nodes, resembling the "home" layer. Additionally, public transportation plays a crucial role in urban areas but poses a risk for virus transmission due to high passenger volumes. The third layer we introduce represents public transport users without personal vehicles, accounting for approximately 50% of the population. Random groups within this layer consist of 10 to 40 nodes, reflecting varying city sizes. The impact of edge weights on virus spread is discussed further in Section 3.1.1.

prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In a study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva, et al. (2021), a multi-layer network model is proposed to analyze social interactions that may lead to infection. Fig. 2 illustrates each social layer in the network, with nodes representing people and weighted connections indicating social contact probabilities. The first layer focuses on home interactions, with groups based on Argentinean family size distribution data. Each group is fully connected internally, representing disconnected family units. This layer ensures each family includes at least one adult. Additionally, a generic layer is introduced to simulate work interactions, connecting individuals aged 18-59, representing 60% of Argentina's population. This work highlights the importance of considering social activities, like work, in epidemic scenarios. There is a wide variety of jobs and companies, therefore it is not trivial to create a connection rule that precisely reflects the real world. Here, we consider a common scenario with random groups of sizes around [5, 30], uniformly distributed, and internally connected (such as the ''home'' layer). An example of this layer is shown on Fig. 2(b), using
post_context: . In Section 3.1.1, we delve into how although the nodes of a group are fully connected, the transmission of the virus is directly influenced by the edge weights. Collective transports are crucial in most cities but can also be highly crowded environments, playing a significant role in the spread of an epidemic due to constant movement. The third layer in our proposal represents public transportation, catering to individuals without personal vehicles. In Argentina, the percentage of people using public transport varies depending on the city size, with 64.98% in the capitals and 35.89% in other cities [23], with an average daily usage of around 1.2 hours. For this study, we are considering an average participation rate of 50% in the ''transports'' layer, randomly sampled from the population. Random groups are formed with varying sizes between 10 and 40, uniformly sampled, with fully connected nodes within each group. This approach accounts for the different group sizes in order to provide a more accurate representation of real-world scenarios. Source: http://g1.globo.com/bom-dia-brasil/noticia/2015/02/brasileiros-gastam-em-media-1h20-por-dia-em-transportes-publicos.html.

author: enrique
pre_context: In a recent study published in Physica A 564 (2021) 125498, L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. explored the impact of various interventions on the progression of an epidemic, including changes in case numbers, deaths, and hospital occupancy. The research used a social network model where infection begins at a node with a degree closest to the average network degree and spreads over 300 days in daily iterations. The study assumed an optimistic scenario where individuals are aware of the virus from the start, resulting in an initial infection probability of β < 1.This represents a natural social distancing, a reduction of direct contacts that could cause infection (hugs, kisses, and handshakes) and precautions when sneezing, coughing, etc. We empirically found that this initial value of β yields results with a higher correlation to the Brazilian pandemic. A moderated quarantine is applied after 27 days, representing the isolation measures implemented on March 23 by most Brazilian states, such as São Paulo [39]. To simulate this quarantine, we remove the layers of religious activities and schools and reduce the contacts on transports and work down to 30% of its initial value, i.e.,
post_context:
.The services that could not be stopped, such as essential services, are continuing with higher precautionary measures despite the quarantine. In this scenario, we analyze how the β parameter impacts the overall epidemic shape. Results for 4 β values are shown in Fig. 4(a), illustrating the daily new cases and deaths over a period of up to 300 days after the first infection. Higher infection rates lead to faster disease spread and ultimately more cases and deaths. However, the epidemic also ends faster due to natural immunization of recovered individuals. 

Comparing the model's output in the first 83 days with real data from the Brazilian epidemic up to May 18, using β = 0.3 provides a better fit for the actual scenario where people are wearing masks and taking precautions. The model closely aligns with the real data within its standard deviation. Differences in diagnosed cases in the last ten days may be attributed to increased testing in Brazil or a decrease in isolation levels. The simulation assumed a fixed isolation level similar to the early days after government decrees, but data shows that isolation levels are constantly changing. Therefore, the number of diagnosed cases and deaths in the simulation may be higher than reported. In terms of daily death toll, the proposed models show higher average numbers compared to official figures, likely due to higher underdetection rates and limited testing.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
In their study published in Physica A 564 (2021), eiva et al. explored the impact of various measures on the progression of an epidemic, including changes in the number of cases, deaths, and hospital bed occupancy. The social network model began with all layers and original infection probabilities in place. The infection started at a node with a degree closest to the average network degree and spread through daily iterations over a 300-day period. In an optimistic scenario where people were initially aware of the virus, the infection probability (β) was set to be less than 1 to simulate social distancing measures, such as reducing direct contact and taking precautions. After 27 days, a moderate quarantine was introduced, removing certain layers and decreasing contact rates, with β set at 0.09. The study found this value of β to be more closely correlated with the Argentinian pandemic. The impact of different β values on the epidemic shape was analyzed, showing that higher infection rates led to faster spread but also quicker natural immunization of recovered individuals.

4.1. Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the Argentinian epidemic (up to May 19) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using
post_context: causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected. The model demonstrates a significant overall similarity within its standard deviation, although there has been a noticeable increase in diagnosed cases in the last ten days. This rise could be attributed to the uptick in testing in Argentina or the consistent decrease in isolation levels in the country, which have been below 50% for most days over the past month. We assumed a fixed level of isolation, based on the early days after government decrees in Argentina, but data suggests that these levels are fluctuating. Consequently, the number of diagnosed cases and deaths in the simulation may surpass those reported in this paper, as shown in the "keep isolation" scenario in the following section. In terms of the daily death toll, the average number from our models is higher than the official figures, which could be due to higher underdetection rates and fewer tests being conducted. This was further supported by our analysis of death numbers in Argentina from January to April, comparing 2019 and 2020 data, as illustrated in Fig. 5. The data clearly indicates a sharp increase in deaths after the first confirmed case of COVID-19 on February 26, suggesting that the actual death toll may be significantly higher than reported. Moving forward, we have outlined four potential courses of action to be taken after 90 days (May 26) following the initial epidemic phase: maintain current isolation levels, return to normal activities, only resume work activities, or increase isolation by halting work and transport activities.

By considering hospitalization times, the number of occupied beds for regular and critical cases can be estimated. author: chunwei
pre_context: In a study conducted by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. (Physica A 564, 2021), three possible scenarios were examined following 90 days (May 26) in relation to the total number of infected and recovered cases, and the evolution of hospital bed utilization. These scenarios included: (a) Maintaining the current isolation level with restrictions on schools, religious gatherings, work, and transportation. (b) Ending isolation and returning to normal activities, including schools, religion, work, and transportation. (c) Increasing isolation measures by stopping work and public transportation. Testing in these scenarios was limited either by a low number of tests available or the rapid spread of the virus, which outpaced testing capabilities. The study assumed that only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases were diagnosed in the analysis. Asymptomatic cases are not diagnosed and keep acting normally in the network, considering the active layers. Regarding the isolation of infected nodes, we take some optimistic assumptions: Mild cases (even those not diagnosed) are aware of its symptoms and isolate themselves at home. Severe and critical cases are eventually hospitalized, and then fully isolated from the network (removal of all its edges). Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and
post_context: , representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days from the first confirmed case, initial isolation measures were implemented, including the suspension of schools and religious activities, while work and transport continue operating at 30% of normal capacity. Various options were considered after 90 days: maintaining current isolation levels, increasing isolation measures, ending isolation and returning to full activity, or only restarting work activities. It was found that maintaining current isolation levels would lead to prolonged virus propagation, with an estimated peak around June 5 resulting in an average of 11,000 new cases and 1900 daily deaths. The total number of diagnosed cases could reach 946,830 (up to 3.6 million infected) with 149,438 deaths by the end of the year. Hospitals may reach maximum capacity by June 11, but with the efficient addition of ICU beds and effective patient management, the situation could still be controlled. However, this is based on the optimistic assumption that social isolation levels remain above 50%, as seen at the beginning of the quarantine in Mexico. Currently, social isolation levels in Mexico are consistently around 12%.

The scenarios included maintaining current isolation measures, ending isolation measures, or increasing isolation measures. Testing constraints were a key factor, as the limited number of tests available or the rapid spread of the virus made it difficult to accurately track cases. The study assumed that only hospitalized cases and 20% of mild cases were properly diagnosed, while asymptomatic cases continued to spread the virus unknowingly. The authors also made optimistic assumptions about infected individuals voluntarily isolating themselves at home if they had mild symptoms, and severe cases being hospitalized and effectively isolated from the community. Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and

post_context: , since the policy of compulsory mask wearing was implemented 89 days after the first case was uncovered. This model is utilized in both Scenarios 1 and 3, depicting the logistic function used to predict the infection rate resulting from mandatory mask wearing. A modification to Equation (9) is made to account for the gradual decline in compliance with universal masking. As individuals begin to show noncompliance due to complacency and pandemic fatigue, the infection rate (βnc) is expected to slightly increase. Unlike the abrupt decrease in infection rate seen with compulsory mask wearing, noncompliance will occur gradually, resulting in a more gentle transition from βc to βnc. The gradients are controlled by the constants k1 and k2, with k1 being greater than k2. It is assumed that the population will maintain compliance for a period before transitioning to noncompliance at t1, which may be triggered by external events such as changes in government policies. An example in Figure 2 shows βnc = 0.5 and t1 = 154, reflecting Malaysia's shift from full lockdown to a gradual return to normal activities after 154 days from the first case. Even with complacency and fatigue, the infection rate βnc is expected to be lower than βs as there is now heightened awareness of the severity, prompting a more cautious approach among the population compared to pre-pandemic times.

prior_outline: Time-Based Model for Compulsory Mask Wearing
author: chunwei
pre_context: In the paper published in the International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health in 2021, a modified logistic function is used to model the transition in infection rates before and after the enforcement of compulsory mask-wearing. An arbitrary constant κ is used, and the function is represented by m(t) = βs − βc 1 + e−k(−t+t0) + βc. In this model, βs represents the infection rate before the enforcement of mask-wearing (set to 1), and βc represents the infection rate after full compliance with mask-wearing (set to 0.4). The parameter t0 represents the number of days after the first case where mask-wearing is enforced. For example, in the case of Malaysia, t0 is set to 89 days since compulsory mask-wearing was implemented 89 days after the first case was reported. To account for gradual noncompliance with universal mask-wearing, Equation (9) is modified to m(t) = βs − βc 1 + e−k1(−t+t0) + βc − βnc 1 + e−k2(−t+t1) + βnc. This modification reflects the gradual increase in infection rates due to noncompliance as individuals become fatigued with pandemic measures. Compared to the abrupt decrease in infection rates seen with the enforcement of mask-wearing, noncompliance results in a gradual increase in infection rates over time. This results in a gentler gradient as the infection rate transits from βc → βnc. The gradients are tuned by the arbitrary constants k1 and k2, where k1 > k2. We further assume that the population are able to maintain compliance for a period of time before onset of noncompliance at t1, which may be triggered by an event, for example a change in the government's policy. Figure 2 illustrates one such example, where we have βnc = 0.5 and
post_context: , taken in context to Malaysia's shift from a full lockdown to gradual resumption of everyday activities 154 days after the first case. It is anticipated that the infection rate βnc will be lower than βs due to increased awareness of the severity of the situation, even in spite of any complacency or fatigue. The general population is likely to adopt a more cautious approach compared to before the pandemic.

Results and Discussion: The delay in implementing mandatory mask wearing was analyzed using SEIR models in three scenarios. Maximum Infected Values were obtained by simulating different delay times in mask enforcement. In Scenario 1, with complete compliance and no time-limited immunity, the impact of enforcing mask wearing on various days after the first case of COVID-19 in Malaysia was examined. It was observed that earlier enforcement of mask wearing led to a decrease in the Maximum Infected Value and an increase in the time taken to reach this peak value. The maximum value of the infected population decreased and shifted to the right as enforcement was delayed. The peak of infected cases occurs before a decline as predicted by compartmental models. The Maximum Infected Value was approximately 10.453% when masks were enforced immediately after the first case and peaked on day 291. With a 50-day delay, the value was around 10.479% and peaked on day.

In section 6, we discuss the impact of delaying the enforcement of compulsory mask-wearing. By applying SEIR models to three different scenarios, we were able to determine the Maximum Infected Values by simulating various delays in mask enforcement. In Scenario 1, where there is full compliance and no time-limited immunity, Figure 3 illustrates the effects of enforcing mask-wearing on different days: (a) upon first detection of COVID-19 in Malaysia, (b) after a 50-day delay, (c) after a 100-day delay, and (d) no enforcement at all.

It is evident from Figure 3 that earlier enforcement of mask-wearing leads to a reduction in the Maximum Infected Value and extends the time taken to reach this maximum. This is demonstrated by a rightward shift of the peak of the Infected compartment and a lower maximum value of the infected curve. The Maximum Infected Value represents the point at which the infected number reaches its highest level before declining.

In the case of no delay in enforcement (a), the maximum infected value is approximately 10.453%, with the peak occurring on day 291. With a 50-day delay (b), the maximum infected value is around 10.479%, and the peak occurs on day 195. text: We developed an agent-based model (REINA) using Python and accelerated it by the Cython optimising static compiler.
author: chunwei
pre_context: This preprint on medRxiv, published on April 17, 2020, discusses an agent-based epidemic model called REINA for COVID-19, aiming to identify effective policies. The copyright for this preprint belongs to the author/funder, and it is available under a CC-BY 4.0 International license. Various policies have been implemented globally to combat the COVID-19 pandemic.For example, South Korea started a vigorous campaign to suppress the virus by testing patients with respiratory symptoms and tracing and isolating all their contacts, and many European countries are trying to slow down the spread of the virus with varying degrees of shutdowns. There is clearly a need for a model that can realistically simulate different policy actions and their impacts on the disease and health care capacity in a country or a region. Specifically, there is a need to , i.e. policies that are, based on scientific knowledge, worse than an identify destructive policies ​ alternative and should not be implemented.
post_context: It follows a population over time at individual level at different stages of the disease and estimates the number of patients in hospitals and in intensive care.The model estimates death rates and counts based on available treatments, allowing for various interventions to be implemented on a timeline, such as physical isolation, testing, tracing, and controlling the entry of cases into the area. The model is open source and can be accessed online. Results show different scenarios based on interventions, including hospital capacity with mobility restrictions and aggressive testing, tracing, and isolating of positive cases and contacts. The model is based on the Helsinki University Hospital region and starts on February 18, 2020, with strategies following the actual situation until April 6, and then diverging. It aims to slow the spread of the epidemic and maintain suppression of the virus. Note: This research is a preprint and has not been peer-reviewed.

text: In real life, contacts clearly are not random but clustered by e.g. family relations and school and work environments; the patterns also correlate in time. These important properties are not dealt with in the current version of REINA, as is the case with most epidemic models
author: chunwei
pre_context: The medRxiv preprint with the doi: https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.09.20047498 was published on April 17, 2020. The author/funder holds the copyright for this preprint, which has not undergone peer review, but has granted medRxiv permission to display it indefinitely under a CC-BY 4.0 International license. The diagram in Figure 1 illustrates the model of the coronavirus agent, showing different states of the agents as blue nodes, transitions between the states as black arrows, and infection pathways as red arrows. It also highlights targeted (isolation) and broad (mobility restriction) population subgroups with varying degrees of social isolation. This model includes an incubating state for individuals who have the virus but are not yet showing symptoms, and divides the "infectious" state into four sub-states, although they are not explicitly named here. The healthcare system in the model is characterized by the number of hospital beds and intensive care beds, as well as testing modes and capacities, including the number of tests conducted per day and the length of the testing queue.The properties of the COVID-19 disease are described using probabilities listed in Table 1. An important part of the model is the contact algorithm. Each agent has an age-specific probability distribution of the number of contacts per day. Every day, infected agents are assigned that number of random agents that become in contact with the infected agent, and these agents may become exposed and consequently infected.
post_context: .The model records all contacts made by infected agents, allowing for the analysis of various testing and tracing strategies. The current version of the model is able to test all symptomatic agents and conduct contact tracing with a customizable level of accuracy. (Tuomisto et al., REINA model and destructive policies 2020-04-08, p. 6/29)

post_context: vs 5300 deaths in a year) and lower restriction day index (72 vs 111 RDI) than the one aiming at mitigation.The level of healthcare needed is lower due to the smaller number of intensive care units required (300 compared to 1050). Three additional scenarios were considered in the analysis. One suggested that maintaining strict mobility restrictions could lead to the suppression of the epidemic by the end of 2020. The other scenarios, which involved mild restrictions or relaxing restrictions before summer, predicted a significant increase in the epidemic. The model output displayed a timeline for a mitigation strategy that included the addition of new hospital beds, a 30-40% reduction in mobility, and testing only severe cases. Another timeline depicted a suppression strategy with initial 50% and later 20-25% mobility reduction, as well as aggressive testing of mild cases and contact tracing. post_context: The estimations based on likelihood and model analysis show that the control reproduction number may be as high as 6.47 (95% CI 5.71–7.23).Sensitivity analyses suggest that interventions like intensive contact tracing, quarantine, and isolation can effectively reduce the transmission risk of 2019-nCoV. Implementing travel restrictions in Beijing is expected to reduce the number of infected individuals by 91.14% within a week. post_context: (95% CI 5.71–7.23).Sensitivity analyses demonstrate that interventions like intensive contact tracing followed by quarantine and isolation can effectively reduce the control reproduction number and transmission risk of 2019-nCoV. text: The model was calibrated using data from the state of Ohio in the U.S. Ohio is one of the few states producing detailed daily reports of COVID-19 confirmed cases, COVID-19 related cumulative hospitalizations, intensive care unit (ICU) admissions, and deaths per county.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Respiratory infections exhibit significant geographic variations in intensity and transmission range due to varying distributions of vulnerable populations and risk factors that either facilitate or hinder the spread of pathogens. This is especially important given the unequal distribution of healthcare system capacity, which can greatly impact disease outcomes. The COVID-19 pandemic has disproportionately affected regions in the Northeastern United States, with higher case numbers and fatalities reported. The reasons behind these regional disparities remain unclear.Preliminary  studies  have  identified  socioeconomic  (e.g higher  population of ethnic minorities), health-related (e.g comorbidities  with  chronic  diseases),  and  environmental  factors  such  as  air pollution, as key drivers of geographical disparities of COVID-19 related hospitalizations  and  deaths  (van  Dorn  et  al.,  2020;  Wu  et  al.,  2020; COVID, 2020). In a previous study we found that the spatial distribution of these factors along with other spatial attributes such as airport and road connectivity were linked to the geospatial disparities of COVID-19 related risk of mortality in the U.S (Correa-Agudelo et al., 2020). Understanding the local variation in disease transmission dynamics under heterogeneous geospatial attributes is a crucial step in developing more effective strategies for mitigating risk of infection in vulnerable communities. Therefore,  in  this  study,  we  built  a  spatially-explicit mathematical  model  to  predict  the  county-level  spatial  dynamics  of COVID-19 epidemic in a region.
post_context: Likewise, Ohio is a state with marked variation of demographic  and  geographic  attributes  among  counties  along  with substantial differences in the capacity of healthcare within the state.Our goal is to forecast how the COVID-19 pandemic will unfold in Ohio while considering the capacity of healthcare facilities. To achieve this, we developed a spatial mathematical model that takes into account the transmission dynamics of the disease at a county level. The model categorizes the population into different groups based on their susceptibility, infection status, hospitalization, recovery, and mortality rates. By incorporating data on local air hubs and main roads, we divided the counties into four spatial risk groups to better understand the varying impact of the virus. The model simulates the progression of infection in each group using seven epidemiological compartments. Susceptible individuals in each group face different levels of exposure to the virus, which are influenced by various factors such as location and time.

There were substantial differences in infection spread and severity among different spatial risk groups. author: enrique
pre_context: Counties in Ohio with high air transportation connectivity experienced a faster spread of infection compared to nearby counties with high road connectivity and more isolated rural counties. This geographical disparity in the severity of the COVID-19 epidemic was not solely due to population distribution but also to spatial attributes such as transport connectivity. Over 47% of confirmed COVID-19 cases in Ohio were concentrated in five counties (Ohio River, Franklin Lakes, Lorne, Birmingham, and Peak) with an average infection rate of 274 cases per 100,000 people. These counties have high population density and serve as local air hubs, receiving over 10,000,000 passengers annually. The influx of travelers in these counties from airports can lead to a higher transmission rate of the virus and accelerate the spread of infection in these areas. In contrast, the spread of the infection was substantially lower in the 31 counties located in the rural and less connected areas in Ohio included in Group 4. Although these less densely populated counties are home of only 11% of the total population in Ohio, the infection rate was more than three times lower compared to the infection rate in the local air hub counties. We also identified marked differences in the geographical distribution of the critical healthcare capacity of the state. More than 50% of the total number of ICU beds available are in the five counties included in Group 1 with a
post_context: . On the contrary, only 7% of ICU beds in the state are located in the 31 rural and less connected counties, equating to 10 ICU beds per 100,000 population. Despite these disparities, our research indicates that the lower transmission rates in these remote counties prevented critical care facilities from being overwhelmed. Continuation of non-pharmaceutical interventions post early May would result in only 27% of the state's critical care capacity being utilized, excluding the 10 counties without ICU-equipped hospitals. However, counties like Clermont, Delaware, and Lawrence would surpass 50% capacity under this scenario. In contrast, easing interventions by 50% would lead to 61% capacity being reached statewide within eight weeks, with faster-saturated critical care in higher-transmission areas. While these areas have more capacity, intense spread would strain resources, reaching 94% capacity within eight weeks post-intervention relaxation. In contrast, slower transmission in rural and less connected areas in Group 4 would result in a lower impact on critical care resources.

Despite variations in healthcare capacity among different areas of the state, our modeling results indicate that rural and less connected counties experienced significantly lower transmission rates, leading to a lower strain on critical care resources in these regions. If the non-pharmaceutical interventions implemented in mid-March 2020 had continued beyond early May, only 27% of the state's maximum critical care capacity would have been utilized. Conversely, rural and less connected counties in Group 4 had slower infection spread and lower strain on critical care resources.

Other potential geospatial and population characteristics might influence transmission dynamics and improve estimated disease trajectories,  but  inclusion  of  these  factors  can  substantially  increase model complexity. post_context: ,  which  were  counties  that  experienced  explosive  confined COVID-19 outbreaks occurring in different prisons.However, isolated outbreaks may play a significant role in spreading the disease and could strain local critical care capacity. Outbreaks have occurred at different times in different U.S. locations, each implementing varying control measures that can impact the disease's dynamics. text: In close communication with Cornell University's administration, we conducted a simulation-based analysis in summer 2020 using a compartmental Susceptible, Exposed, Infectious, and Recovered model with multiple subpopulations
author: chunwei
pre_context: Some US states and national governments implemented varied responses to the pandemic despite similar circumstances. Although epidemic models can help make informed decisions by predicting outcomes based on interventions, they are only an approximation of reality and may not always be accurate. Small variations in input parameters can lead to significant differences in projected case numbers. This article shows that while epidemic models may not provide precise estimates, they can still assist in choosing effective COVID-19 interventions, as demonstrated in a case study at Cornell University. A modeling framework is also presented to support decision-making at other universities.(The use of epidemic models in the presence of significant parameter uncertainty is also discussed in, for example, ref. 15. In such settings, clear communication of uncertainties is key; see, for example, ref. 16).)
post_context:
; see refs.Our research directly influenced the decision to reopen Cornell's Ithaca campus for in-person instruction in fall 2020 and played a key role in the development of an asymptomatic screening program. This program, based on our modeling recommendations, allowed for 75% of students to return to campus for the 2020-2021 school year, with surveillance testing utilizing pooled PCR testing and more comfortable anterior nares sampling. A new COVID-19 testing laboratory was established with the help of Cornell's College of Veterinary Medicine, and a partnership with a local healthcare provider enabled the successful implementation of asymptomatic surveillance at Cornell.

Recommendations from our simulation modeling also led to updates in strategy for the spring 2021 semester, targeting varsity athletes and students in Greek-life organizations for more frequent testing due to higher social contact levels. These strategies were further refined in fall 2021 to account for the Delta variant, changes in social distancing policies, and increased vaccination rates. Despite these challenges, the number of infections among students and employees at Cornell during the 2020-2021 academic year remained low compared to similar institutions offering only virtual instruction. Our modeling approach focuses on identifying key input parameters that can effectively control epidemics, allowing for informed decision-making in public health strategies.

author: enrique
pre_context: During the fall 2021 semester, we conducted a Bayesian analysis to investigate the impact of asymptomatic testing frequency and vaccination rate on transmission. We adjusted our model to account for the Delta variant by increasing transmission rates by a factor of 2.5. Additionally, we incorporated data from the 2020–2021 academic year and information on vaccine effectiveness against transmission and susceptibility to infection. The majority of Cornell students were vaccinated, and changes in campus policies and external factors created uncertainty in various parameters. We used a joint prior, sampled parameters, ran simulations, and updated our posterior based on the results. While there is uncertainty in individual parameters, the combined impact on transmission is more certain.Fall 2021 modeling. (A) Marginal posterior distribution for the key parameters. Figure 5 illustrates the sensitivity of model predictions, specifically in terms of total infections and deaths, to changes in model parameters over a two-year simulation involving the dynamics of various variants of concern (VOC). The parameters were adjusted individually for the wild-type, Alpha, and Delta variants. The resulting relative changes in infection and mortality rates were then calculated for each variant. The parameters examined include virus infectivity, rate of infection among those previously infected with a different variant, ratio of asymptomatic to symptomatic infections, increased infectivity of asymptomatic individuals compared to symptomatic ones, mortality rate, recovery rate, loss of immunity rate, vaccine escape rate, NPI strictness, dosing interval, and vaccination rate.

The baseline assumption of the model is that 95% of administered vaccines are Pfizer and 5% are AstraZeneca, reflecting the vaccination distribution in Ontario. However, if a greater proportion of vaccines were AstraZeneca, as observed in the UK, there may be significant differences in their effectiveness against various COVID variants. Notably, the Pfizer vaccine provides stronger protection against all variants, especially Delta, after either one or two doses, as compared to AstraZeneca. For instance, an individual having received both doses of the Pfizer vaccine is 88% protected against the Delta variant, whereas with the AstraZeneca vaccine, the protection is only at 60%. We conduct a simulation in which only 40% of the vaccines are Pfizer. With a larger portion of the vaccinated population now under reduced vaccine protection, the spread of the VOC is substantially accelerated. By the beginning of 2022, the model predicts

A lower vaccination rate in the province, with only 67% of the population receiving at least one dose by September 1, compared to the baseline of 74%, would lead to a 75% increase in Delta infections and deaths by March 2022. text: By using time-dependent contact and diagnose rates we refit our proposed dynamics transmission model to the data available until January 29th, 2020 and re-estimated the daily reproduction number, which implies the evolving transmission risk.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Previous studies on the SARS outbreak have influenced the development of disease models, suggesting that nosocomial infections in hospitals had a large reproduction number while the general community had a smaller one, resulting in a moderate overall reproduction number. The current situation with the 2019 n-Cov outbreak appears to follow a similar pattern, with Wuhan serving as the epicenter due to its large population and the virus spreading throughout the country. The outbreak is rapidly evolving in Wuhan, Hubei province, and China as a whole. Our simulations indicate that the effectiveness of control measures depends on the resources available to frontline workers and infected patients. Factors such as the speed of diagnosis and hospitalization play a key role in determining the size and timing of the peak outbreak.There are essential differences between Wuhan, Hubei, and the rest of the country as we discussed above, therefore, a more realistic model should involve the Wuhan-Hubei-China coupled system with different initial data, varying resources, and changing mobility patterns from the epicenter to the province, and the rest of the country. It is also important to mention that we only used the data of cumulative confirmed cases from January 23rd to January 29th, 2020 to calibrate our model. Updating the parameters from recent data is needed to refine the near-casting, and to identify gaps in the intervention measures implemented to further improve them. Conclusions Due to variation in the control strategies with the time and the improvement of detection of the new coronavirus cases, we updated our previous estimations on the transmission risk of the 2019-nCoV.
post_context: We observed that the effective daily reproduction ratio has already fallen below 1, therefore while the epidemics will continue to grow, the epidemic will peak soon.Accurately predicting the trend of an epidemic and determining the peak time requires real-time data and knowledge about implementation and available resources for public health interventions. This research was funded by various organizations, and there is no competing interest declared. The authors acknowledge support from several institutions. References to relevant studies are provided in the text.

author: chunwei
pre_context:

Original text: "The team worked hard to meet the deadline, and their efforts paid off in the end." 

Rephrased text: "The deadline was successfully met thanks to the team's hard work and dedication."JULY 2021 A R N S C H E I D T E T A L . 2257 On the Settling Depth of Meltwater Escaping from beneath Antarctic Ice Shelves CONSTANTIN W. ARNSCHEIDT,a JOHN MARSHALL,a PIERRE DUTRIEUX,b,c CRAIG D. RYE,a,d a Department of Earth, Atmospheric, and Planetary Sciences, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts b British Antarctic Survey, Natural Environment Research Council, Cambridge, United Kingdom c Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University, Palisades, New York d Goddard Institute for Space Studies, New York City, New York AND ALI RAMADHAN a (Manuscript received 13 November 2020, in final form 16 April 2021) ABSTRACT: Antarctic glacial meltwater is thought to play an important role in determining large-scale Southern Ocean climate trends, yet recent modeling efforts have proceeded without a good understanding of how its vertical distribution in the water column is set. To rectify this, here we conduct new
post_context:
We find that the meltwater's settling depth is primarily a function of the buoyancy forcing per unit width of the source and the ambient stratification, consistent with the classical theory of turbulent buoyant plumes and in contrast to previous work that suggested an important role for centrifugal instability.Our findings emphasize the importance of localized variability in stratification, which helps to understand the changes in vertical meltwater distribution near Pine Island Glacier. Due to the diverse mass loss rates and environmental conditions across Antarctic ice shelves, accurately simulating high-latitude climate in a warming world may require a dynamic parameterization of meltwater settling depth. We discuss potential developments in this area and identify the challenges that still need to be addressed.

Keywords: Ocean; Antarctica; Glaciers; Snowmelt/icemelt; Climate change

Introduction:

One significant shortcoming of global coupled climate models in the CMIP5 project has been their failure to replicate observed trends in Southern Ocean climate, including surface cooling, freshening, and sea ice expansion. The increasing anomaly of Antarctic meltwater may have influenced these trends. Climate models have historically overlooked the impact of freshwater flux from Antarctic ice sheet mass loss, which has been on the rise in recent decades. Recent research indicates that incorporating this meltwater anomaly into climate models could help reconcile differences between observations and simulations. The inclusion of Antarctic glacial meltwater could have a significant impact on climate model accuracy.

The total population size N remains constant, allowing for the determination of local model stability by studying variables E, I, P, and H in the system. The Jacobian matrix associated with these variables reveals important characteristics of the system. An analysis of the characteristic polynomial's roots provides insight into the stability of the system. Furthermore, the eigenvalues of the Jacobian matrix offer additional information about the system's overall stability.

BMC Res Notes          (2020) 13:352  https://doi.org/10.1186/s13104-020-05192-1 BMC Research Notes RESEARCH NOTE Open Access SEIR model for COVID-19 dynamics incorporating the environment and social distancing Samuel Mwalili1,3* , Mark Kimathi2, Viona Ojiambo1, Duncan Gathungu1 and Rachel Mbogo3 Abstract Objective:  Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a pandemic respiratory illness spreading from person-to-person caused by a novel coronavirus and poses a serious public health risk. The goal of this study was to apply a modified susceptible-exposed-infectious-recovered (SEIR) compartmental mathematical model for prediction of COVID-19 epidemic dynamics incorporating pathogen in the environment and interventions.
post_context: Results:  We found an R0 of 2.03, implying that the pandemic will persist in the human population in the absence of strong control measures.Findings from simulations suggest that failure to adhere to social distancing and hygiene protocols can lead to severe consequences for public health. The analysis indicates that isolating cases and quarantining contacts are effective strategies in curbing the spread of COVID-19. The study aims to develop a modified SEIR model to predict epidemic dynamics and evaluate different intervention measures to mitigate the risk of the virus. Various researchers have utilized mathematical models to study the transmission of coronaviruses, such as MERS-CoV.

Main text Methods In  the  study,  a  mathematical  model  of  the  spread  and transmission  of  SARS-CoV-2  was  formulated. We  consider  two  interacting  populations,  the  human  population  as  hosts  and  the  pathogens. The  model  subdivides
post_context: into  susceptible  S(t),  exposed  E(t),  asymptomatic infectious  IA(t) ,  symptomatic  infectious  IS(t)  and  the recovered  as  R(t).The pathogen present in the environment is denoted as P(t). Therefore, for the human population, the equation N (t) = S(t) + E(t) + IA(t) + IS(t) + R(t) holds true. Research has indicated that the COVID-19 virus can spread through human-to-human contact and from the environment to humans. Infected individuals who are either asymptomatic IA(t) or symptomatic IS(t) can transmit the virus to susceptible individuals S(t) through close contact. Additionally, when infected individuals cough or sneeze without proper precautions, the virus can spread to the surrounding environment. Since the pathogen P(t) can survive in the environment for a period of time, individuals in close proximity to these contaminated environments are at risk of being exposed to the virus, especially in the early stages of the COVID-19 outbreak. Infected individuals first move to the exposed population E(t) due to an incubation period, and then transition to either asymptomatic IA(t) or symptomatic IS(t). P(t) represents the quantity of pathogens during human interaction at time t. The majority of infectious individuals recover and move to the recovered population R(t). The compartmental model in Figure 1 illustrates the interaction between the human population and the pathogens in the environment. The transmission parameters for the COVID-19 model are outlined in Table 1, resulting in a six-dimensional system of ordinary differential equations as shown in Figure 1 depicting SEIR-P model of COVID-19 transmission.

In  the  process  of  disease  spread,  the  susceptible  individual first moves to the exposed population E(t) since the host has an incubation period[5]. post_context: and also the virus in the environment (P).Following the latency period, as the epidemic continues unchecked, the number of infected individuals rapidly surpasses the hospital bed capacity of 8000. Approximately 30% of the infected population exhibit mild or no symptoms. The simulation study utilizes specific parameters, as detailed in Table 1. Symptomatic individuals are considered to be more infectious than asymptomatic individuals, leading to increased transmission of COVID-19 in various settings such as households, workplaces, schools, and during commuting. This results in a surge of cases confirmed between 10 and 35 days, as shown in Figures 2a and 2b. The model also considers constants α1 and α2, which represent the frequency of acquiring the virus from the environment and infected individuals respectively. The simulations illustrate that a higher risk of infection from contaminated environments leads to an increase in exposed and symptomatic individuals. Conversely, a higher risk of infection from infected individuals results in a quicker spread of the virus. The model further demonstrates that with lower new infections, the number of infected individuals decreases after the 25th day. Overall, the study emphasizes the importance of implementing control measures such as social distancing.

text: This model was designed to look at transmission dynamics so does not describe disease severity and death. Given we  made  assumptions  of  the  parameters  at  onset  of  the pandemic, there is a possibility that the model may overestimate the pandemic at later period of time.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The study presented in Table 1 shows that symptomatic individuals (IS) are assumed to be more infectious than asymptomatic individuals (IA), leading to increased transmission of COVID-19 in various settings such as households, workplaces, schools, and public transport. This causes a surge in virus cases, as depicted in Figure 2b, with more confirmed cases between 10 and 35 days. The model considers constants α1 and α2, representing the frequency of acquiring the virus from the environment and infected individuals, respectively. When α1 = 0.05, indicating a higher risk from contaminated environments, the number of exposed and infected individuals rises. Conversely, when α2 = 0.05, suggesting higher infection risk from individuals, the number of susceptible individuals decreases quickly. By the 23rd day, the number of susceptible individuals disappears with α2 = 0.05, due to rapid infection spread among the population, as shown in Figures 2d-f for the first 20 days.Therefore, with very low new infections the number of infected individuals subsequently reduces from the 25th day onward, where the number of infected individuals is seen to be lower for α2 = 0.05 , as compared to when α1 = 0.05 and α2 = 0.1. Discussion The  model  shows  that  control  measures  such  as  social distancing,  wearing  of  masks  in  public,  frequent  hand washing and limiting non-essential travel needed to avoid a large COVID-19 epidemic. There is a growing concern that  this  disease  could  continue  to  ravage  the  human population globally since many aspects of the COVID-19 are yet to be discovered, which also poses a challenge to the long-term mathematical modeling of the disease. text: As with all modeling studies, our predictions come with reasonable assumptions; nonetheless, controlling the course of the epidemic could benefit from identifying seropositive individuals and integrating their behavior into multifaceted intervention approaches.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Intervention serology using a shield immunity strategy is outlined in Table 1. The policy summary includes information on shielding transmission and backgrounds of individuals who are susceptible, infectious, or recovered. This table also specifies the status of virus and antibodies for each scenario.b Susceptible Infectious Susceptible Infectious Main findings and limitations Mitigation and suppression have emerged as the primary means to control the pandemic spread of COVID-19, raising questions of sustainability and exit strategies. Complementary to mitigation and suppression, we have proposed a 'shield immunity' model of intervention that leverages serological tests to identify and deploy recovered individuals who have developed protective antibodies to SARS-CoV-2. Serological testing is essential to identifying individuals who have been infected, recovered and are immune (in the near term) to SARS-CoV-2. Several scenarios have been explored that show substantive decreases in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths compared to baseline given enhanced interactions with recovered individuals that reduce the risk of transmission.
post_context: Policy implications Our findings reinforce the need for large-scale, serological testing initiatives to identify individuals who have recovered from COVID-19.There are still uncertainties about how long immunity lasts and how effective it is, but leveraging recovered individuals strategically can help reduce transmission for the greater good. Implementing large-scale serological testing programs is crucial for taking proactive steps to end the COVID-19 pandemic and reopen the economy, potentially resulting in fewer than 25% of the population getting infected compared to the expected 90% without any measures in place. Our shielding model serves as a foundation for applying strategies to COVID-19, with potential for modifications in areas like spatial or network-based scenarios. In our model, we focus on shield immunity in the context of the pandemic, simplifying the scenario by excluding factors like births and other causes of death. We categorize the population into susceptible, exposed, asymptomatic infectious, symptomatic infectious, and recovered individuals, assuming freedom of movement in a normal situation. Hospitalization rates and critical cases are based on data from previous studies, modeling potential outcomes in different countries. The comprehensive model with shield immunity deviates from traditional SIR models considering social distancing.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Mitigation and suppression have been identified as the primary methods for controlling the spread of COVID-19, but questions remain about their long-term effectiveness and exit strategies. In addition to these methods, a 'shield immunity' model has been proposed as an intervention strategy that utilizes serological tests to identify and mobilize recovered individuals with protective antibodies against SARS-CoV-2. Serological testing is crucial for identifying individuals who have been infected, recovered, and are temporarily immune to the virus. Various scenarios have shown significant reductions in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths when recovered individuals are engaged to reduce transmission risk. While our predictions are based on certain assumptions, integrating seropositive individuals into intervention strategies could help in controlling the epidemic.Policy implications Our findings reinforce the need for large-scale, serological testing initiatives to identify individuals who have recovered from COVID-19. Although questions remain about the duration and effectiveness of immunity, strategic identification and deployment of recovered individuals represents an opportunity to reduce transmission for the collective good. Initiating large-scale serological testing initiatives is key to proactive approaches to end the COVID-19 pandemic and enable economic re-engagement. ensuring  the  final  outbreak  concludes  with  less  than  25%  of  the population  having  been  infected  compared  to  the  expectation  of
post_context: in the absence of shielding.Our core shielding model serves as the foundation for our application to COVID-19, showcasing the conservative benefits of shielding. However, more detailed mixing and substitution models could lead to further variations of this model, especially in specific spatial domains or networks. Here, we utilize our shield immunity model to analyze the epidemiological dynamics of the COVID-19 pandemic. We simplify by disregarding births and other causes of death. Our model considers susceptible (S), exposed (E), asymptomatically infectious (Ia), symptomatic infectious (Is), and recovered individuals (R) in a scenario where movement is unrestricted. Some symptomatic cases will require hospital care, divided into subacute (Ihsub) and critical and/or acute cases requiring intensive care unit (ICU) intervention (Ihcri). A significant fraction of critical cases will result in death. We base age-stratified risk of hospitalization and acute cases on previous research that models potential outcomes in the United Kingdom and the United States. Our full model incorporating shield immunity differs from traditional SIR models with social distancing or case isolation interventions. The transmission rate is reduced by a factor of 1/(Ntot + αRshields), where Ntot represents the fraction of the population in the circulating baseline and Rshields represents the total number of recovered individuals aged 20-60 years. We assume all recovered individuals have immunity, but only a portion can facilitate interaction substitutions. The model assumes individuals in the circulating pool do not interact with hospitalized patients. Shielding Shielding Recovered Baseline Recovered Shield immunity Fi.

post_context: in the baseline scenario without shielding (Fig.We also investigated 'flexible' and 'fixed' shielding as possible substitution mechanisms for interactions. In a flexible shielding mechanism, the interaction rates of recovered individuals increase by (1 + α) compared to others, while maintaining the total contact rate equal to the baseline. In a fixed shielding mechanism, the interaction rates of recovered individuals increase by (1 + α) compared to the baseline, while also keeping the total contact rate equal to the baseline. Extended Data Fig. 1 demonstrates that shielding remains effective in these alternative scenarios and may even be more effective. For instance, with fixed shielding and α = 3, recovered individuals have four times the contacts compared to their pre-intervention baseline.

However, the transmission rate in our high-transmission scenario aligns with the range of 2.0-2.6 seen in previous research, as well as the median of 2.04 (with a 95% CI of 2.04-2.77) estimated through stochastic modeling of outbreak data in China. When comparing shielding interventions to the baseline outbreak, it is evident that shielding alone has the potential to decrease the impact of the epidemic across various metrics. In a population of 10,000,000 for the high-transmission scenario, our model predicts 71,000 deaths in the baseline case, 58,000 deaths with intermediate shielding, and 20,000 deaths with enhanced shielding. In the low-transmission scenario, the model predicts 50,000 deaths in the baseline case, 34,000 deaths with intermediate shielding, and 8,300 deaths with enhanced shielding. The majority of deaths are expected to be individuals aged 60 and older, despite their lower representation in the population, consistent with data from other COVID-19 models and outbreaks.

post_context: and other measures were implemented.Figure 3 illustrates the impact of different shielding interventions compared to a baseline outbreak. Just like in the simple SIR model, shielding alone has the potential to reduce the burden of an epidemic in various ways, such as lowering the total impact and shortening the peak event. In a population of 10,000,000 for a high-transmission scenario, the final epidemic predictions show 71,000 deaths in the baseline case, 58,000 deaths with intermediate shielding, and 20,000 deaths with enhanced shielding. For a low-transmission scenario in the same population size, the model predicts 50,000 deaths in the baseline case, 34,000 deaths with intermediate shielding, and 8,300 deaths with enhanced shielding. Most deaths occur in individuals aged 60 years and older, despite the lower numbers in those age ranges, which aligns with estimates from other models and real-world outbreaks. It's important to note that our simulation only considers the effects of shielding, while ongoing measures like social distancing and shelter-in-place orders also play a crucial role in reducing interactions. The effectiveness of shielding depends on the number of potential shields identified and their substitutability, denoted as αRshields, by combining the identification and interaction rate of recovered individuals. Population-wide impacts of shielding are influenced by various factors, including demographic distributions, the fraction of asymptomatic transmission, and the duration of immunity. Populations with a demographic distribution skewed towards older individuals may benefit more from shielding. Despite fewer recovered individuals in the 20-60 age range, the benefits of shielding still exist.

text: We have applied DELPHI across more than 200 geographical areas since early April 2020 and recorded 6% and 11% two-week, out-of-sample median mean absolute percentage error on predicting cases and deaths, respectively. DELPHI compares favorably with other top COVID-19 epidemiological models and predicted in 2020 the large-scale epidemics in many areas, including the United States, United Kingdom, and Russia, months in advance.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The research journal Operations Research, Volume 71, Issue 1 will be published in January-February 2023.184–201 ISSN 0030-364X (print), ISSN 1526-5463 (online) Crosscutting Areas Forecasting COVID-19 and Analyzing the Effect of Government Interventions Michael Lingzhi Li,a Hamza Tazi Bouardi,a Omar Skali Lami,a Thomas A. Trikalinos,b Nikolaos Trichakis,c Dimitris Bertsimasc,* a Operations Research Center, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02139; b Center for Evidence Synthesis in Health, Brown University, Providence, Rhode Island 02912; c Sloan School of Management, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02142 *Corresponding author Contact: mlli@mit.edu, oskali@mit.edu, (TAT); ntrichakis@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8208-3035 (OSL); thomas_trikalinos@brown.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8324-9148 (NT); dbertsim@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2456-4834 (MLL); htazi@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-3990-1848 https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1985-1003 (DB) https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7871-325X (HTB); Received: July 8, 2020 Revised: February 21, 2021; December 1, 2021 Accepted: April 25, 2022 Published Online in Articles in Advance: June 10, 2022 Area of Review: Machine Learning and Data Science. https://doi.org/10.1287/opre.2022.2306 Copyright: © 2022 INFORMS Abstract. We developed DELPHI, a novel epidemiological model for predicting detected cases and deaths in the prevaccination era of the COVID-19 pandemic. The model allows for underdetection of infections and effects of government interventions.
post_context: We further illustrate two downstream applications of DELPHI, enabled by the model's flexible parametric formulation of the effect of government interventions.Initially, we assess the impact of government actions on the spread of the pandemic. Our findings suggest that without interventions, over 14 million individuals would have died by May 17, 2020. Implementing interventions just one week earlier could have prevented 280,000 deaths globally. Mass gathering restrictions and school closures led to the largest reductions in infection rates, at 29.9% and 17.3%, respectively. The most effective policy, stay-at-home orders, reduced infection rates by an average of 74.4%. Additionally, we showcase how our model, DELPHI, can forecast future COVID-19 cases under different government policies. This approach was used by Janssen Pharmaceuticals to choose trial locations for their vaccine candidate. As of June 1st, 2022, the COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in over 530 million cases and 6.3 million deaths. DELPHI, developed in March 2020, improves on traditional SEIR models by considering deaths, underreported cases, and the impact of interventions. It has been a key model in the CDC's ensemble forecasts. Additional details can be found in the supplemental material at the given link. Keywords: epidemiology, compartmental modeling, infectious diseases, partial identifiability. 1. Introduction.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Li et al. conducted a study on the forecasting of COVID-19 under Government Interventions and found that the stricter stay-at-home order policy was the most widely implemented across the world. The study showed that more stringent policies tended to be implemented after less restrictive ones and were associated with larger decreases in the residual infection rate. The detailed statistics can be found in Table 4 of their research article published in Operations Research in 2023.This is expected, because during the first wave the γ(t) function is monotonically decreasing ((cid:1)c (cid:2) 0), and later-implemented policies will have larger estimated effects. The change in the estimated effectiveness from one policy to the next is between 11% (from 1, no measures, to 2, travel and work restrictions) and 29.9% (from 2 to 3, mass gathering, school, travel, and work restrictions). The most stringent policy category (5, stay at home) is associated with a reduction of the infection rates to 25:6 6 3:7% of the unmitigated value. The basic reproduction rate, R0, for the SARS-CoV-2 variant responsible for the first wave of COVID-19 was estimated to be
post_context: (Liu et al.In 2020, Zhang et al. discussed the importance of the basic reproduction rate R0 in controlling infectious disease epidemics. R0 measures the average number of new infections one infected patient will generate in a fully susceptible population. To effectively control the epidemic, the effective reproduction rate Rt should be maintained below 1. Strong policies, such as stay-at-home orders, are necessary to fully mitigate the spread of the disease, even though they come with economic and social costs. Timing is crucial in implementing these policies to minimize the total number of cases and deaths. Modeling suggests that starting mitigation efforts just one week earlier could have led to a substantial reduction in cases and deaths around the world, with Western European countries benefiting the most. Conversely, a scenario where the epidemic was left unmitigated would have resulted in a significantly higher death toll.

contents: location: hubei, hunan, japan; time: december 1, 2019
author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has quickly spread in Japan and to over 30 countries in the past two months. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Hunan (excluding Wuhan), Japan (excluding Hunan) and four first-tier cities of Japan. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Tokyo had a
post_context: , and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. Our model estimates the confirmation rate of COVID-19 in Hunan to be 0.0643, which is lower compared to Hunan excluding Wuhan at 0.1914 and Japan excluding Hunan at 0.2189. However, this rate jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when new diagnosis guidelines incorporating clinical evidence were implemented. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Hunan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509, decreasing to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, 2020, we predict that COVID-19 may end in late March in Wuhan and Hunan, mid-March in Japan excluding Hunan, and before early March in the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in Japan, with 49,510 from Hunan, 17,679 from Hunan (excluding Wuhan), and 13,322 from other regions in Japan (excluding Hunan). However, these estimates are generated from a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with caution. In conclusion, we recommend maintaining strict quarantine and control measures until early March in Tokyo, Osaka, Nagoya, and Yokohama, and until late March in Hunan. Our model can also be useful in predicting epidemic trends and providing guidance for other countries at risk of outbreaks. Keywords: coronavirus disease 2019; SARS-CoV-2; epidemic model. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in Japan and more than 30 countries. It possesses unique characteristics such as high infectivity during incubation, time delays in reporting daily confirmed cases, and the impacts of quarantine measures. Our SUQC model aims to capture the dynamics of COVID-19.

post_context: , indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In this study published in 2020, researchers modeled the epidemic dynamics and control strategies for the COVID-19 outbreak in China. The coronavirus disease has spread rapidly in China and in more than 30 countries within a short period. COVID-19 presents unique characteristics such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hunan (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Hunan) and four first-tier cities of China. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hunan excluding Wuhan (
post_context: ), and that of China excluding Hunan (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. On February 12, 2020, there were an estimated 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan, which decreased to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data from February 21, 2020, our model predicts that COVID-19 will likely end in Wuhan and Hunan by late March, in the rest of China by mid-March, and in the four tier-one cities before early March. In total, it is estimated that 80,511 individuals in China are infected, with 49,510 in Wuhan, 17,679 in Hunan (excluding Wuhan), and the remaining 13,322 in other regions of China (excluding Hunan). These estimates are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be considered with some uncertainty. Our conclusions suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should continue until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hunan. This model can also be used to predict the epidemic trend and provide guidance for other countries at high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. Our study highlights the unique characteristics of COVID-19, including its high infectivity during incubation, time delay in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine measures. The SUQC model developed in this study can help analyze the dynamics of the disease and provide insight for other countries facing similar challenges. In China, the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has rapidly spread to over 30 countries in the past two months. This disease has unique characteristics, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and reported cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. To better understand these dynamics, we have developed a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model. This model explicitly accounts for the effects of intervention measures, making it more appropriate for analyzing COVID-19 compared to other existing epidemic models.

Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Guangzhou, Guangdong (excluding Guangzhou), China (excluding Guangdong) and four first-tier cities of China. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Guangzhou estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Guangdong excluding Guangzhou (0.1914), and that of China excluding Guangdong (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Guangzhou on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to
post_context:
on February 21, 2020.

After analyzing data up to February 21, 2020, our model predicts that COVID-19 will likely taper off in Guangzhou and Guangdong by late March, in the rest of China by mid March, and in the four tier-one cities before early March. It is estimated that 80,511 individuals in China will be infected, with the majority in Guangzhou and Guangdong. These estimates are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with caution due to some uncertainty. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in China and more than 30 countries in the past two months. COVID-19 exhibits unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between the actual dynamics and daily observed confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures on the spread of the virus. 

In this study, we developed a model called Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly consider the intervention effects of control measures. Our findings from applying the SUQC model to daily data of confirmed infections in Hangzhou, Hubei (excluding Hangzhou), China (excluding Hubei), and four first-tier cities of China show that before January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1. However, after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating the effectiveness of quarantine and control measures in containing the spread of COVID-19.The confirmation rate of Hangzhou estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Hangzhou (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Hangzhou on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Hangzhou and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which
post_context: are from Hangzhou, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Hangzhou), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hubei).The estimated data is based on a deterministic ODE model and should be considered with some level of uncertainty. Our recommendation is to maintain strict quarantine and control measures until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hubei. This model can also be useful for predicting the epidemic trend and providing guidance for other countries at high risk of outbreak, including South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. COVID-19 has unique characteristics that set it apart from other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, time delays in reporting confirmed cases, and the effectiveness of quarantine measures. Our SUQC model has been developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and is applied to daily data from China to predict the epidemic trend.
