author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Accepted on March 4, 2020, the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in Japan and over 30 other countries within the last two months. This disease exhibits unique characteristics such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between the actual dynamics and the daily number of confirmed cases, and the impact of implemented quarantine and control measures. A Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model was developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19. This model explicitly considers the effects of control measures, making it more suitable for analysis compared to other epidemic models. The results of the SUQC model applied to daily data of confirmed infections show the outbreak of COVID-19 in different regions of Japan. It was observed that, prior to January 30, 2020, all regions, except for Tokyo, had a reproductive number R > 1. However, after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures have been effective in containing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Tokyo estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Japan excluding Tokyo (0.1914), and that of Japan excluding Tokyo (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Tokyo on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Tokyo and Japan is around late March, around mid March for Japan excluding Tokyo, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in Japan, among which 49,510 are from Tokyo, 17,679 from Japan (excluding Tokyo), and the rest
post_context: from other regions of Japan (excluding Tokyo). The estimates provided in this study are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be considered with some level of uncertainty. Our findings suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should be maintained in Tokyo, Yokohama, Nagoya, and Osaka until early March, while in Japan these measures should be in place until late March. Our model can be used to predict the epidemic trend and offer guidance for countries at high risk of outbreak, including South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. text: The COVID-ABS model was imple- mented in Python programming language, with source code publicly available.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The COVID-19 pandemic caused by the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus has had a significant impact on global public health and economies. V.C. Batista and colleagues from various research institutions in Brazil have conducted a study on epidemic models and agent-based simulation to analyze the effects of the pandemic. This article was received on June 9, 2020, revised on June 26, 2020, and accepted on July 2, 2020. It is now available online since July 7, 2020.To overcome this problem, countries have adopted different policies and non- pharmaceutical interventions for controlling the spread of the virus. This paper proposes the COVID-ABS, a new SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered) agent-based model that aims to simulate the pan- demic dynamics using a society of agents emulating people, business and government. Seven different scenarios of social distancing interventions were analyzed, with varying epidemiological and economic effects: (1) do nothing, (2) lockdown, (3) conditional lockdown, (4) vertical isolation, (5) partial isolation, (6) use of face masks, and (7) use of face masks together with 50% of adhesion to social isolation. In the impossibility of implementing scenarios with lockdown, which present the lowest number of deaths and highest impact on the economy, scenarios combining the use of face masks and partial isolation can be the more realistic for implementation in terms of social cooperation.
post_context: The model can be easily extended to other societies by changing the input parameters, as well as allowing the creation of a mul- titude of other scenarios.Hence, it serves as a valuable tool for guiding policymakers and health authorities in their response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The ongoing outbreak of Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), was first identified in Wuhan, China, in December 2019. The World Health Organization (WHO) labeled it a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on January 30th, 2020, and a pandemic on March 11th. In Brazil, the initial confirmed case occurred on February 25th, 2020, with a man from São Paulo testing positive for the virus. Since then, Brazil has been heavily impacted, with over 1,220,000 confirmed cases and more than 55,000 deaths as of June 26th, 2020, as reported by the Brazilian Ministry of Health. Besides the public health crisis, the coronavirus crisis has affected various aspects of life, including politics, education, economy, social interactions, environment, and climate. It has also caused significant disruptions to global supply chains and production. The most effective means of combating the disease is by enforcing strict social distancing measures on the population, as evidenced by numerous studies and reviews. Many countries are implementing such measures with varying levels of success. Given the complexity of societies, predicting the consequences and outcomes of these interventions is challenging.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
Taking uncertainties in data into account involves allowing the data at each time point to follow a probability distribution with a mean determined by the assumed model and a variance determined by the assumed probability distribution, which may be influenced by the mean. However, the lack of data is a more significant concern for modellers. One key factor contributing to the variability in model predictions is the relationship between available data (confirmed cases) and model predictions. Confirmed cases refer to individuals with symptoms who sought medical attention, were tested, and received positive results for COVID-19 through DNA or imaging tests. The infected compartment in transmission models encompasses all infected individuals, whether symptomatic or asymptomatic, those who have been tested and confirmed, and those who may have been misdiagnosed. Thus, confirmed cases represent only a portion of the total infected population predicted by the model. An analogy of an iceberg can be used to illustrate this distinction. The entire iceberg symbolizes the total infected population, with the visible tip above the water surface representing the confirmed cases. The submerged part of the iceberg indicates the infected individuals not detected through public health surveillance and testing, often referred to as the hidden epidemic.

The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021, the
post_context:
, based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2021).

Why is this a concern for modelers? In model calibration, it is important to estimate key parameters like the transmission rate b by adjusting the model output to match confirmed cases data. To make accurate predictions, the total number of infectious people I(t) in the model must be adjusted by the case-infection ratio r. By finding the best fit between the model and data for different values of r, the transmission rate b can be estimated and used to determine the basic reproduction number R 0 and the peak time of the epidemic. However, since the case-infection ratio for COVID-19 can vary widely, the estimated transmission rate b also has a wide range, leading to a variety of model predictions. This variability in parameter values that can fit the data well but lead to different predictions is known as nonidentifiability in modeling literature. How nonidentifiability is managed during model calibration greatly impacts the reliability of predictions. Standard optimization methods like nonlinear least squares may struggle to address nonidentifiability effectively, as they aim to find a global minimum but may encounter countless such minima.

author: chunwei
pre_context: If the difference in the Deviance Information Criterion (Di) for model i is less than 7, then that model has less support. If the Di value is greater than 10, then model i has no support and can be omitted. When dealing with a large number of models or non-nested models, the rules for model selection are different. For more information on model selection, please refer to recent lecture notes by Portet (2020).3. Model selection analysis for an SEIR and an SIR model We used both SEIR and SIR frameworks to model the COVID-19 epidemic in Hangzhou, and we applied model selection analysis to decide which framework is more parsimonious. 3.1. The models In our SIR and SEIR models, the compartment S denotes the susceptible population in Hangzhou, compartment
post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases. In the SEIR model, a latent compartment E represents individuals who are infected but not yet infectious. This latency in COVID-19 is biologically realistic, as the virus can have an incubation period of up to 14 days, during which newly infected individuals may not be contagious. It is important to differentiate between the latent period, which is the time from infection to infectiousness, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to the onset of symptoms like fever and coughing. While in the SARS model infected individuals become infectious about two days after symptoms appear, COVID-19 has shown evidence of individuals being infectious before symptoms arise. The SEIR model is more biologically realistic but has the drawback of having two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and the initial latent population. The transfer diagrams for both models are presented in Fig. 1, and the biological interpretations of the parameters are detailed in Tables 1 and 2. It is assumed that deaths in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible during the prediction period of the models (4 months). The differential equations for each model are provided below for calibration using newly confirmed case data, which matches the rI term in both models, making the death term in the R compartment irrelevant for model fitting.

Here we distinguish between the latent period, which is the time from infection to being infectious, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to clinical symptoms like fever and coughing for COVID-19. For SARS, individuals become infectious on average two days after symptoms appear, making the latent period longer than the incubation period. Infected individuals with COVID-19 can be contagious before symptoms occur, but the length of the latent period is not well understood. post_context: the initial population size E0 for the latent compartment E on January 22, 2019, and b, r, I0, and q ¼ 1=t.After the mayor of Hubei announced at a news conference on January 23 that 5 million people had left the city by that date, we estimated the total population N to be around 6 million on January 22. Utilizing a uniform distribution over initial parameter ranges as priors for both the SIR and SEIR models, we employed the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm to generate posterior distributions for all estimated parameters. The best-fit values and 95% credible intervals were then obtained from these distributions, as displayed in Tables 1 and 2 for the SIR and SEIR models, respectively. Upon comparing the calibration results, we calculated their corrected Akaike Information Criterion (AICc) to be 174 and 186 for the SIR and SEIR models, respectively. The significant difference of 12 between the AICc values suggests that using the SEIR model would result in a loss of information compared to the SIR model. Therefore, further investigations will proceed with the SIR model. Additionally, a linkage between the transmission rate (b) and diagnosis rate (r) was identified based on the calibration results of the SIR model, as depicted in Figure 2.

author: enrique
pre_context:
Data from various sources can be utilized for model calibration, including technical, surveillance, or administrative data, as well as information from published literature. However, this can be challenging during real-time outbreaks of unknown pathogens, like SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19 situation. One alternative is to utilize improved inference methods and model fitting algorithms to reduce the large confidence or credible intervals. Our fitting procedure, which involved Bayesian inference and an affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, successfully accomplished this goal.

Baseline predictions for Nanchang were generated using prediction intervals from randomly sampling the posterior distribution. Table 1 displays the best-fit parameter values and credible intervals. The Bayesian inference utilized newly confirmed case data from official reports in Nanchang between January 21 and February 4, 2020, which was during the lockdown and travel restrictions in the city. These projections provide an estimate of the potential epidemic in Nanchang if no further control measures were implemented after February 7, 2020. Figures 4(a) and (b) illustrate the distributions of the projected peak time and estimated values of the control reproduction number R c.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Nanchang together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 26, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 22 - March 5.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. Based on our estimate, if strict quarantine measures are not implemented after February 7, the number of peak cases would potentially reach around 120,000, and the epidemic in Nanchang would likely continue until mid-May 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
PLOS COMPUTATIONAL BIOLOGY Covasim: A model for COVID-19 dynamics and interventions
The duration of COVID-19 symptoms and viral shedding can vary greatly, with durations typically increasing according to the severity of the illness. In our model, we account for this by assigning different recovery times for asymptomatic individuals, those with mild symptoms, and those with severe symptoms. Non-critical cases are assumed to recover, while critical cases may recover or face a higher risk of death, particularly with increasing age. 

When a susceptible individual interacts with an infectious individual, there is a probability of virus transmission occurring (β). In a well-mixed population where each person has an average of 20 contacts per day, a β value of 0.016 equates to a doubling time of approximately 4-6 days and an R0 of about 2.2-2.7. The exact values can vary based on population size, age demographics, and other factors. The β value of 0.016 used in Covasim was derived from calibrations to data from Washington and Oregon states and is currently set as the default in the model.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.The assigned weightings of 10:2:2:1 were chosen to align with previous research on time-use surveys and infections with known contact types. These values also provide a weighted mean similar to the default β value of 0.016 for a population without multiple network layers. In the absence of interventions, transmission events are estimated to occur approximately 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community in a typical transmission scenario. Interventions such as physical distancing can alter the value of β. Individual differences in disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and infectivity are considered by allowing variations in viral load. Viral load is modeled to have an early high stage followed by a longer low stage, with the high stage set to be twice as high as the low stage. The default viral load for each individual is determined by a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape parameter 0.45, which aligns with international estimates and data from specific regions. Daily viral load values are used to adjust the per-contact transmission probability (β) for each individual. An illustration of viral loads for individuals with default parameters is provided in Fig 2.

author: enrique
pre_context: Therefore, the parameter β should be adjusted by the user based on local epidemic data, as outlined in Section 2.6.8. If the network structure includes realistic settings like households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts, the transmission probability for each contact type varies. The default values are around 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community, with relative weightings of 10:2:2:1. These values were chosen to align with time-use surveys and studies on known contact types, and to have a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a mixed population. When considering the default number of contacts in each layer, age-based susceptibility, and other factors, in an unmitigated scenario, transmission events are roughly 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. Interventions like physical distancing can also impact the value of β. Furthermore, individual infectiousness can vary between people and over time, and differences in infectivity are modeled using individual viral load. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Washington state. The daily viral load is used to adjust the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an individual each day. Fig 2 displays viral loads for a sample of individuals with default parameter values. The proportions of transmissions by asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals can vary by location, with estimates for Seattle provided in [25]. The evidence regarding whether transmissibility is lower in individuals without symptoms is inconclusive [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not lower, but we allow for the adjustment of this parameter based on the specific modeling context, as some studies have suggested much lower infectiousness rates for asymptomatic individuals [61].
